content.text:
### Proof Sketch
- For each fixed b in A, let N_b^p(n) be the total number of occurrences of the part b among all partitions of n with parts in A. Then N_A^p(n)=∑_{b∈A} N_b^p(n).
- A partition of n that contains b exactly k≥1 times contributes k to N_b^p(n). Such partitions are in bijection with partitions of n−kb (with parts in A) together with the choice “append k copies of b”; summing over k yields ∑_{k≥1} p_A(n−kb)=N_b^p(n).
- Passing to generating functions gives ∑_{n≥0} N_b^p(n) x^n = (x^b/(1−x^b)) ∏_{a∈A}(1−x^a)^{−1}. Summing over b yields (a).
- Expanding ∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1−x^b)=∑_{m≥1} τ_A(m) x^m and ∏_{a∈A}(1−x^a)^{−1}=∑_{k≥0} p_A(k) x^k, Cauchy product and coefficient extraction give (b).
- For distinct partitions, in a partition each part b appears at most once, so N_b^q(n) equals the number of distinct partitions of n that contain b. Removing b gives a bijection with distinct partitions of n−b using parts from A\{b}, whence ∑_{n≥0} N_b^q(n) x^n = x^b ∏_{a∈A\setminus{b}}(1+x^a) = (∏_{a∈A}(1+x^a)) (x^b/(1+x^b)). Summing over b gives (c).
- Finally, use ∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1+x^b)=∑_{m≥1} τ_A^s(m) x^m and ∏_{a∈A}(1+x^a)=∑_{k≥0} q_A(k) x^k to derive (d) by coefficient extraction.

### Proof
We work throughout with formal power series in x. For a set A of positive integers:
- The ordinary generating function for partitions with parts in A is
  ∑_{n≥0} p_A(n) x^n = ∏_{a∈A} (1−x^a)^{−1},
  since each part a may be used with multiplicity 0,1,2,… contributing the factor 1+x^a+x^{2a}+…=(1−x^a)^{-1}.
- The ordinary generating function for distinct partitions with parts in A is
  ∑_{n≥0} q_A(n) x^n = ∏_{a∈A} (1+x^a),
  since each part a is either present once or not at all.

(a) Fix b∈A and define N_b^p(n) to be the total number of occurrences of the part b among all partitions of n with parts in A. If E_k(n) denotes the number of such partitions in which b occurs exactly k times, then N_b^p(n)=∑_{k≥1} k E_k(n). On the other hand, appending k copies of b induces a bijection between partitions of n−kb with parts in A and partitions of n in which b occurs at least k times; hence p_A(n−kb)=∑_{j≥k} E_j(n). Summing over k≥1 and exchanging summations,
∑_{k≥1} p_A(n−kb) = ∑_{k≥1} ∑_{j≥k} E_j(n) = ∑_{j≥1} j E_j(n) = N_b^p(n).
Therefore
∑_{n≥0} N_b^p(n) x^n = ∑_{n≥0} ∑_{k≥1} p_A(n−kb) x^n = (∑_{k≥1} x^{kb}) (∑_{m≥0} p_A(m) x^m)
= (x^b/(1−x^b)) ∏_{a∈A} (1−x^a)^{−1}.
Summing over b∈A and using N_A^p(n)=∑_{b∈A} N_b^p(n) yields
∑_{n≥1} N_A^p(n) x^n = (∏_{a∈A} (1−x^a)^{−1}) (∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1−x^b)),
which is (a) (there is no constant term because N_A^p(0)=0).

(b) Expand the second factor in (a):
∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1−x^b) = ∑_{b∈A} ∑_{t≥1} x^{bt} = ∑_{m≥1} (∑_{a∣m, a∈A} 1) x^m = ∑_{m≥1} τ_A(m) x^m,
and the first factor as ∑_{k≥0} p_A(k) x^k. By Cauchy product, the coefficient of x^n (n≥1) on the right-hand side equals
∑_{k=0}^{n-1} p_A(k) τ_A(n−k).
Thus (b) follows.

(c) For distinct partitions, define N_b^q(n) to be the total number of occurrences of b among all distinct partitions of n with parts in A. Since multiplicities are 0 or 1, N_b^q(n) equals the number of distinct partitions of n that contain b. Removing b gives a bijection between such partitions and distinct partitions of n−b with parts from A\{b}. Therefore
∑_{n≥0} N_b^q(n) x^n = x^b ∑_{m≥0} q_{A\setminus\{b\}}(m) x^m = x^b ∏_{a∈A\setminus\{b\}} (1+x^a)
= (∏_{a∈A} (1+x^a)) (x^b/(1+x^b)).
Summing over b∈A and using N_A^q(n)=∑_{b∈A} N_b^q(n) gives
∑_{n≥1} N_A^q(n) x^n = (∏_{a∈A} (1+x^a)) (∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1+x^b)),
which is (c).

(d) Expand the second factor in (c):
∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1+x^b) = ∑_{b∈A} ∑_{t≥1} (−1)^{t−1} x^{bt}
= ∑_{m≥1} (∑_{a∣m, a∈A} (−1)^{m/a−1}) x^m
= ∑_{m≥1} τ_A^s(m) x^m,
and the first factor as ∑_{k≥0} q_A(k) x^k. Coefficient extraction for x^n (n≥1) yields
N_A^q(n) = ∑_{k=0}^{n-1} q_A(k) τ_A^s(n−k),
which is (d).

All four assertions (a)–(d) are proved. ∎
